required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Baby Bump Lifestyle Intervention Supplement Study
clinical_study.official_title: Baby Bump Lifestyle Intervention Supplement Study

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York at Buffalo

clinical_study.source: State University of New York at Buffalo

brief_summary.textblock: The overall purpose of this study is to examine how natural supplements can mediate the effects of stress on fetal development during pregnancy.

clinical_study.why_stopped: IRB had concerns about study; terminated

primary_outcome.measure: lower blood stress markers via venous draw
primary_outcome.description: We hypothesize that the addition of nutrients during gestation will decrease the levels of stress hormones/reactants in pregnant women who are at high risk for stressful pregnancies.

intervention.description: Supplement will be given to this group to take daily for 8 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant woman presenting to her first obstetrical visit for this pregnancy
- Must be in the first trimester (<13 weeks)
- 18 years or older
- High-stress levels as measured by the Perceived Stress Level Questionnaire
- Must be a single pregnancy (e.g. not twins, triplets, etc.)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diabetes (types 1 and 2)
- Diagnosis of gestational diabetes in prior pregnancy
- Hyperemesis gravidarum or severe morning sickness that interferes with supplement intake
- Major medical illnesses including but not limited to: malabsorption syndromes (Celiac's disease, Crohn's, Ulcerative Colitis), Systemic Lupus Erythematosus and other major autoimmune conditions

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: State University of New York at Buffalo
